author: Miami
title: I can't appreciate rude staff
body:
My GP surgery referred me urgently to eye casualty in January around teatime. They said that the surgery had inappropriately referred me and I could try NEMS. I have never been to NEMS before but decided to go in and ask the waiting time.  
There was one trained nurse on the reception desk but when I tried to ask the question, as they didn't listen to me they barked inappropriate questions at me (thinking I was a relative). I said I had my urgent referral letter and I was a patient and they barked at me to sit down, saying they were busy doing something, then vanished leaving no staff there.  
I waited a short while and decided I didn't like the tone of the department if that was a snapshot of it and there seemed to be a few waiting so I left. As I went to push open the door who should be pulling it open but the rude nurse, as a patient/member of the public did they hold it open for me? No, they pushed through and never even acknowledged me.  
I can appreciate a busy department but I can't appreciate rude staff, they choose to work there at the end of the day. They might have been having a bad day but did they know about mine?

author: Sunshine2627
title: Mixed care
body:
I had an early scan in December which revealed that I had a missed miscarriage. It was heartbreaking.  
I went in the following day for the surgical management procedure. The Midwive who I was under the care of that day didn't have much empathy considering what I was going through. I felt I was more a number than a patient.  
A couple of days later I was admitted yet again to Rubislaw ward with a suspected womb infection which was terrifying and was utterly traumatic after just what happened a couple of days before this.  
I have to tell you that the Midwife who looked after me that evening was absolutely amazing, she was so supportive, understanding and actually looked after me. I felt like an actual patient.  
I didn't catch her name but would be grateful if you could find out and let her know that she is a credit to the ward and so so lovely. I have to say with all the times I've been to the Maternity Hospital (having 2 healthy pregnancies previously) that evening I was in for an overnight stay in Rubislaw was the best I've been cared for.  
So would like to say thank you to that amazing Midwife who made an awful situation a little easier. She is a star!

title: No contact details
body: My elderly neighbour needed to contact the Ironstone Centre in Scunthorpe and couldn't find a phone number online.  He had not been sent a letter as the appointment was made by phone.  I tried to find a contact number on the NHS website but there is no number listed.  The website has not been updated since 2015.  If a phone number was included then maybe less appointments would be missed.  My neighbour wanted to inform the clinic that his wife was not well enough to attend the appointment.  I doubt he managed to get in contact with the clinic.

title: Excellent care when needed
body: I and my family have been with Church street surgery for little over 9 years and we have no regrets in choosing this surgery. The medical care from the GP’s and Nursing staff has been excellent. This is a surgery that goes over and beyond expectations, where GP’s will contact you well pass their finishing times to keep you informed, that is dedication to care you can’t get everywhere. We have always been able to get an appointment and where necessary we can use the open access system and be seen on the day. At times it may be difficulty to call the practice or make appointments but this is probably due to the demand on the NHS systems as a whole and ever increasing local population. If its quality medical care you are looking for I am more than happy to recommend this practice.

title: Mismanagement in appointments
body: I had an appointment of mid Jan for a small procedure of chronic pain in fifth metatarsal and then it was changed to end of February for some reasons. I called in last week to get a checkup appointment for this worsen pain and swollen joint but that booking lady brought a week forward my appointment instead of booking a routine appointment. KGH is better to organise their appointment and Woodland treats NHS referred patients as inferior patients in regard to cancellation and re-booking of appointment. Very disappointed.

title: Fantastic Practice
body: All doctors here listen and try to provide the best treatment and solution. Refer when necessary, easy to book an appointment and generally appointment times are not delayed. Great patient care by all from administrative staff to clinical staff.

author: ignored relative
title: Lack of care and communication
body:
My uncle who suffers from Parkinson's and quite advanced dementia was admitted to Pinderfields hospital in December. First to ward 41 and later to ward 43. Throughout the experience, I found it almost impossible to get any information from staff despite being a next of kin and also having Power of Attorney for him. I knew he had a UTI as his care home had given me this information and this was not unusual for him due to long term use of a catheter. We went all over the christmas period not really knowing if this was something to worry about or not. Visiting is not an easy option as it is a 40 mile trip and of no real benefit to my uncle as he no longer recognises family. However, this seemed our only option when by the 29th December we had still received no real information and much of the time there was no answer to our calls. I had even rung the PALS office for help and they had promised that someone would call me back. I'm still waiting for that call!!  
My sister and I visited at the end of the month and were shocked at the change in him from only a week before. He had been walking about, chatting and feeding himself and now he was doing none of that and a chat with a staff member revealed that they were talking about end of life care. Why had no one spoken to the family? They led us to believe that someone would talk to us about this but again no call  
A further visit by my sister seemed to contradict this information and we were just left confused'  
Again no call from them but I found that he was to be discharged back to the care home. The staff there were just as shocked as we had been to see the deterioration in him. After only a few hours there he had to be sent back to the hospital as he had been returned without a catheter even though his discharge notes said one was fitted. He then spent all night in A&E before a bed was found for him on ward 41. Still there a number of days later so it does raise the question of should he have been sent out.  
A visit also revealed that not only had he been released without a catheter fitted but he had been released with an end of life care plan which said he should not be sent back to hospital.  
My sister and myself had left a copy of our power of attorney and expressed our wish to be involved in any decisions but this had obviously been ignored and this decision was made without our consultation.  
I am distressed at them releasing my uncle only for him to be returned a few hours later and I am further upset at the lack of communication and compassion we have received from the hospital. I can only hope that communication and care are better than they have been so far.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

title: Great practice
body: Visited this evening , all the staff were very helpful and organised . Waiting time wasn’t too bad . Drinks and snacks were available . Very good service all round

readBy.name: North West Anglia NHS Foundation Trust

title: Can't get through on the phone
body:
Today 20th January, after 36 calls to the surgery I finally got into a queue with 19 other people. I had been trying since 8am.  After being in the queue for 7 minutes the phone cut off. Tried again, got back in the queue and pressed 0 to leave a voicemail. Tried again, in the queue with another 19 people only to get cut off after ten min.

Tried for 45 min to get to speak to someone. On hold while driving to the surgery.  Spoke to a lady at the desk, who surprise surprise had no appointments. You can even book in advance, as I was happy to wait a few days. I could book a 'hub' appointment, but only available for one time and I'm at work. 

No wonder a and e is full if your surgery is like this. 

Couldn't even book a nurse appointment for Feb!  Less than impressed and will have to just try again.  Was a Malling Health patient, since our merge its been Nothing but trouble.

author: Bluepirate1883
title: Excellent and caring
body:
Staff were excellent and caring.  
Fabulous team!

readBy.name: Taunton and Somerset NHS Foundation Trust
Plymouth University Health and Human Sciences students, 2018

title: Excellent care and attention
body:
I recently attended this surgery as a follow up appointment via the practice at Alvechurch. In both instances, my concerns were taken seriously and relevant referrals and treatment plans were made.

From the point of making appointments through to consultations, I cannot fault the service I have received.

title: Poor customer service by the nurse
body: Really poor service by the nurse. No real empathy shown, no real greeting and generally a really bad attitude throughout the appointment. If a caring nature is too much to expect from a trained nurse than I may be wrong.  Being someone that works for the Nhs I have seen great nurses at work and they do an amazing job. I guess I’m more disappointed than anything else.

author: Survivor01
title: They felt more like friends than my carers
body:
I was really ill in 2019 because my Gall bladder ruptured. I was on ICU in an induced coma for 4 weeks & spent another 10 weeks on ward 32. I was under the care of Mr Villatoro.  
Mr Villatoro & another surgeon saved my life. Mr Villatoro saw me nearly everyday whilst I was in Hospital. He & all his team were really kind & caring. They did all they could to make sure I was kept informed. Mr Villatoro made sure my recovery wasn't rushed & always made sure my time with him wasn't rushed.  
The Nurses & Care assistants were fabulous. So were my Physiotherapists. They pushed me when I needed it & shared my joy when I showed improvement. They felt more like friends than my carers.

readBy.name: Sherwood Forest Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Poor service
body: If you have multiple sclerosis then expect no care or compassion. This hospital doesn’t give a hoot about you especially the MS nurses. They do nothing for you whatsoever, and never return calls. It feels like my sister has to beg for her care which is utterly disgusting. MS is a frightening condition and as such, people need the compassion and care they deserve yet these people possess not one iota of it.

title: Excellent & Professional
body: 2 young Paramedics, one training, were brilliant with my mother in law. So professional, caring and sensitive. A credit to the service and to be highly praised! They deserve a massive pay rise from the 'out of touch' Politicians!

title: Appointment follow up
body: Had appointment on 23rd sept at respitory clinic was told will see you in 8 weeks all tests ct scan bloods and breathing tests done and still waiting for follow up appointment.....

readBy.name: East Kent Hospitals University NHS Foundation Trust

author: L x
title: Excellent service
body: I rarely participate in feedback but today I felt that I had to provide praise. My father is a regular outpatient at ward 34. He has lots of medical conditions and staff are always fantastic. Today, as we were very concerned about my Dad, we attended with him. He always insists on going alone. Foundation Doctor Pake was absolutely fantastic in how she dealt with my father. She somehow managed to get him to open up about his fear of hospitals and be truthful about what has actually been happening to him; believe me, this is remarkable. She managed to have a balance of being open, honest, to the point, yet kind, helpful and he trusted her. Her 'way" with him was impressive. Dr Pate's communication/delivery/empathetic skills are impressive. She is an amazing asset for the NHS. Thank you.

title: 08:15 and all today's appointments Gone!
body:
1. People queuing outside today in freezing weather from 7.30am
2. 8:15am  no more GP appointments left.
3. This surgery has 'gone to the dogs'
4. CCG needs to step in, fast before someone dies in the cold waiting to see a doctor.
5. Any wonder why A&E is so busy and people get angry.

readBy.name: Sheffield Health and Social Care NHS Foundation Trust

title: Not helpful
body: I attended my first and second appointment the first wasn't to bad but with the second I'm not sure how drawing a family tree and talking about them was ever going to help when I never mentioned anything about them as that was never the problem I've seen many reviews on here with it also not helping others so now I have to question if it can help people going or if its just a waste of everyone's time

title: Excellent staff
body: After receiving a Urethroplasty operation at Canterbury hospital which genuinely changed my life for the better nearly two years ago I would like to thank all the staff at the Clarke ward Canterbury hospital for their kind and excellent treatment, I have had private treatment prior to this but would never consider going anywhere but with the NHS in the future. Thank you all for giving me back my life following Urethra scar tissue problems.

readBy.name: East Kent Hospitals University NHS Foundation Trust

title: Wonderful Service
body: Having visited my health assistant on fri 10th, feeling very unwell... dizzy, for BP check as was very low. she immediately did ECG as pulse rate was extremely high. Called straight for an ambulance to RHH. Her fast action was fantastic. Will always be so grateful.

title: rubish appointment process and rubish reception…
body: very hard to get appointment and receptionists rubish you have to go stand in cold outside surgery door for appointment  and now change time from 8am to 830 without inform patients

title: Always there to help
body:
The Staff, Nurses and Drs at this surgery have always been attentive and reassuring.

They always seem to strive to get you the next available appointment and I trust their professional opinion.

I have never had any concern with their services.  In particular one doctor and nurse have got me on the road to recovery with my mishaps, to which I am eternally grateful.

title: Surgical team
body: Great team nothing too much bother. Great care. Looked after before during and after surgery with great attention.

readBy.name: Milton Keynes University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

author: Brora
title: Surgical observation waiting area
body:
This waiting area is narrow and claustrophobic for service users. It is a utility closed corridor for staff . This includes their changing room and toilet, their kitchen and private break time space. Service users can hear their conversations through the closed door . The corridor is narrow with chairs facing into each other on both sides . It is not possible for those with mobility aids to sit with their aid beside them and bags etc reduce the corridor with .It was so disheartening to see the white board note asking users to accept that they could sit up to 4 hrs or more in this space .  
A very stressful area to sit . Feels as if users are being held in an area never designed as a waiting area . A waiting area should be bright and airy with a water machine or sign to direct users to refreshments .

title: Excellent treatment
body: A visit was arranged by my GP at very short notice because I had had a TIA.  I was treated by several very calm and helpful staff and given a physical examination, an ECG and a CT scan.  Although it was a Friday evening, and probably a busy time for the department, at no time was this apparent.  Excellent treatment from excellent staff.

author: Happy6
title: My terrifying illness
body: I took a rare autoimmune condition which caused me to be paralysed and very ill for a while. Going from being a very independent healthy person to not being able to do anything was terrifying. I was being fed through a nasogastric tube and had to have a line in my neck. The staff in Dumfries infirmary are second to none. They have been amazing with me. From the nurses, doctors, physio, occupational therapists and speech and language to the anaesthetists, and lots of other staff involved in my care I have nothing but Massive thanks. Especially to the doctors and nurses in critical care and ward c5. And the rheumatology team too. I’m at present in ward c5 and the treatment im getting is the best I could wish for and I’m working with the physio team to get home. I want to thank everyone who has got me where I am. The staff need more recognition. Everybody has been amazing and I genuinely can’t thank them enough.

readBy.name: Royal College of Speech and Language Therapists (RCSLT)

title: Excellent treatment
body: I spoke to the doctor after having had a TIA the previous day.  She provided excellent advice then and followed it up with a call to the local hospital arranging for me to have tests there the same day.  I was reassured after a worrying experience.  Thank you

author: Patient  180120
title: First-class professional service
body:
Attended one stop clinic, got appointment for a Saturday morning clinic. This was brilliant as I work during the week. I was greeted by a friendly receptionist on arrival. I was seen by Dr Meti who was very professional, explained my procedure and I was then taken through to another room. I was greeted by Roxanne who was going to be my Nurse during the procedure. She was brilliant, reassured me throughout the entire procedure.  
An amazing first-class, professional service provided by an amazing NHS.

author: Paizay
title: Hospital to home care for my husband
body: From leaving hospital Dugald had the best of care from the Duns and occasionally Kelso teams. Always caring, helpful and very quickly part of our wider ‘family’. They certainly made the last weeks of my husbands life more comfortable both for him and for me.

author: aries123
title: Made a very difficult situation bearable
body: I’ve been on this ward twice, once following a laparoscopy and again for management of a miscarriage. The nurses really were angels, they really looked after me well and understood the emotional and physical pain I was in. At one stage they thought I had sepsis and took the necessary steps to deal with it. I felt loved and cared for by the nurses at St Mary’s. They made a very difficult situation bearable.

author: Bewareoftheice
title: Pleased to have such friendly and supportive staff
body:
I've had to have a couple of visits to the maternity unit over recent weeks and wanted to thank a few stand out members of staff.  
First off Christine from the ultrasound department was fantastic. She was so calm and reassuring during a 36 week fluid check and filled us with complete confidence that we were in safe hands.  
Secondly, a trip to maternity assessment after a slip in the ice today was quick, efficient and friendly. Dr Abi a friendly and professional ST2 was fantastic and gave us a thorough check over for baby and also a quick ortho review for a sore wrist which was appreciated since I'm sure it's not in his remit to have to check ortho injuries on an obs ward! Dr Abi had obviously taken the time to thoroughly check my notes and knew my history which was appreciated as I didn't have to repeat my story and gave him a sound understanding of my antenatal background. Siobhan, midwife was also very friendly and reassuring. Very patient-centred experience and very pleased to have such friendly and supportive staff in NHS GGC

author: Service User -  Cambs
title: Extremely helpful
body:
I first starting attending the evening group 'lets talk recovery' at CGL Huntingdon approximately 10 months ago. I had already managed to stay sober (with the help of my key worker) for nearly two months. I am now using the group for further support as life goes on.  
The time I spend at the group talking to others who are in the same boat is extremely helpful, and it has made my recovery less lonely.  
This group is currently the only evening group at Huntingdon. I am very grateful it exists because it has been instrumental in my recovery.  
As I approach my first year of sobriety, I feel ready to face what life throws at me.  
Thank you all at CGL Huntingdon!

author: JPR22
title: Kept me updated at all times
body: Very painful fall. NHS 24 were called and they were very helpful. Managed to get to Forth Valley Hospital in Larbert and the treatment I received was incredible. Fast, efficient, effective, very knowledgeable and professional. Everyone was very respectful and concerned, made me feel at ease and explained and kept me updated at all times.

author: Cardiac Rehab Roy
title: Emergency admission.
body:
In the early hours of the morning of the 9th of January, I had what I thought was an episode of Angina. Ambulance was called and the paramedic arrived within minutes, followed immediately by the ambulance crew. Very impressive I must say.  
Admission was quite slick considering how busy the place was.Very organised chaos to say the least. Done and dusted in no time.  
Now off upstairs to ward 4A  
This is where the fun begins. The staff were absolutely tremendous, I won't name names as that would be unfair but the staff will know who they are. Nothing was a problem except me misbehaving making them laugh. It must have been the happiest ward in the building.  
However, time to change wards, along the corridor to ward 4B, that move too went like clockwork. After a day's wait for an MRI scan, after which I was discharged  
Incidentally, it turned out it was not an angina attack. Thanks to Mr Ray and his colleagues to whom I'm very grateful.  
Only one thing, the wait for the MRI scan.

author: Lost for words
title: Discharged only wearing a hospital gown
body: An almost 80 year old gentleman was in the Combined Assessment Unit at Dumfries & Galloway Royal Infirmary. It was decided by them around lunch time he was going to be discharged, I had removed the key for his property from the key safe for security reasons as his property was sitting empty & I was at work that day which caused them a problem as they were desperate to get him discharged that afternoon & I was made to feel like I was wrong for removing his key when really I was just keeping his property secure not expecting to get no notice of his discharge. I had to leave work early to meet the ambulance transport they had arranged but was absolutely disgusted to find he had been discharged only wearing a hospital gown, this was 5pm at night so dark & it was the night of the heavy rain & winds. This gentleman had a bag with 3 sets of clean clothes in & 3 sets of clean pyjamas with him but it was seen fit to discharge this elderly man in only a hospital gown that is open at the back. He lives on a busy street & this was very embarrasing for him never mind the health implications this may have had on him

readBy.name: The Princess Royal Trust  - Dumfries & Galloway Carers Centre
Yorkshire & Humber Patient Safety Research Collaboration

author: volansry33
title: I could not have done it without her
body:
I was extremely anxious when against expectations I received a letter from a consultant indicating that I should go for a Pet scan to investigate a shadow on my lung. My husband accompanied me but I thought he could stay with me, but I had not read that he was only allowed in the waiting area. This got me off to a weepy start.  
I am also claustrophobic and was dreading going into the machine. In addition at a MRI scan last year the veins in my left arms collapsed due to the injection I received.  
Enter Renee. She very quietly dealt with my tears and fears and went to my husband to give him my message about the two hour wait.She took me to see the big machine and offered me a trial run, She dealt with my needle situation, when I was saying that I could not do a cannula, by suggesting the butterfly needle I think it was called. she did my scan, talked me through it and in general due to her expertise, professionalism, and care I actually got the procedure completed. I could not have done it without her and will never be able to thank her enough. My angel and a job so so well done

title: Subject to improvement
body: patients need  one and one service with GP,  and versa vicer.  A GP should know their patients mental, emotional and physical state in order to administer appropriate treatmentSubject

author: J R
title: Thank you so much to all the staff in the labour suite
body:
I'd like to say a massive thank you to all the staff in the labour suite and ward 17 at the BGH. I'm so grateful to everyone of them for looking after me so well, in what has had to be the hardest experience of my life thus far!  
I'd especially like to say a huge thank you to Eunice who worked tirelessly to bring baby Leo into the world. My labour lasted 19 hours with a number of issues cropping up along the way. However, Eunice took everything in her stride, and navigated her way around a number of hurdles beautifully with minimum stress to myself and baby. She allowed me to give birth naturally with no interfence through cuts or foreceps and I can't thank her enough for that! She's an amazing woman!

title: Penalised for Working
body: I need to arrange quite an urgent appointment, but I have to call every morning to get a call back then to get an appointment the same day if there is one available. I work 20 miles away from the surgery & feel this system is unacceptable for people who work

title: Worse unprofessional reception team and gp !!
body:
Nightmare to get answer calls , book appointment , reply to econsult !!!! Even for referrals !!! 
I have been waiting for referral ages keep calling and booking and promising by getting back to me nothing been done and receptionist said they can’t ask another gp although this one didn’t do it for more than 2 month now !!!! Really stressing and frustrating to deal with and to worry about small stuff gp not bothered to do for patents specially who’s having depression and stress disorder!!! Maybe they start working if you do a complain to nhs service

author: Sunray one one
title: Nine days later I remain very impressed
body:
My appointment was with Doctor/Mr Al Jaafari at 9. 00a. m. As I'd been waiting for this appointment for about 2 years and not knowing the parking slots I arrived at about 0730, had breakfast then went up to the 9th Floor. Here I was met by a very courteous gentleman who seemed to be opening things up. Next I met a Nurse who very efficiently took my details and her attitude enabled me to relax. I then met Dr/Mr Al Jaafari. an extremely courteous gentleman who ensured I was fully briefed on what was to occur this morning. This duly happened and I was quite surprised to be released at about 10. 00, just an hour later.  
My feelings were simple. The Surgeon imparted a calmness at the same time ensuring I knew precisely what was to take place..  
The three nurses took a pride in their department. This pride shone through and at the end I was asked to complete my opinion of the event. I have been a bit slow but nine days later I remain very impressed by the sheer efficiency of the department and the pride that the staff have in working to make it feel like a centre of excellence. That just leaves me to say Thank you.

title: Ease of Access
body:
I wear an NHS power chair and have done for the last 20 years; I can walk a little bit but only round my chair. Apart from the physical side I am also autistic.

This hospital is easy to navigate and doors are easy to open and get through; some of the outside areas are awkward, especially the pedestrian ramps.

In the podiatry department, an area that one would expect to have good access as most patients are older people, it is very difficult to manouver a wheel chair or power chair.

Attitudes: generally, all staff are good and are very helpful; there are times, perhaps, when staff are busy or having a bad day, when this slips but that is OK because we are all only human.

Disabled toilets are good and the turning space is generally wider than necessary, though it would make things easier if the doors had a drop hinge that closed the door or a handle on the hinge side of the door to make door closing easier.  Waste bins: some of these are foot-operated - have you tried to use one of these from a wheel chair?

A minor annoyance is sometimes I am required to transfer from my power chair (because it is potentially covered in germs) to a ward wheelchair and then I am left sitting there as though the person has failed to understand that I wear a power chair because I cannot use a manual wheel chair.

As to the germs issue, I have no problem with this, but do query why pedestrians are not required to wear sterile over-shoes?

Finally, thank for having a great hospital and staff.

readBy.name: Sherwood Forest Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: Tutty
title: Nothing was too much trouble
body:
Could not breathe I was scared and felt very ill.  
I was admitted to AMU then c8 ward at Blackburn hospital. Those nurses are superb, nothing was too much trouble. I received excellent care and support.  
They need to know how amazing they really are.

title: Great Practice But Miserable GP and Not…
body: this has been my surgery for years. Overall my experience has been good at this practice, however recently i have noticed one of the doctors is constantly miserable. Does not say hello or welcome with a smile. Maybe it's the job or the hours or bad pay, but miserable individuals are not viewed as approachable and difficult to share ones medical problems with

title: My dad just had  app
body: My dad just had app with the doctor she not interested what the she does not what to do the job and my dad went to c the nurse 11.00 didn't get see 11.30. Very poor doctors don't give one

author: A Lincoln Patient
title: Such a fine team
body: I recently completed a long course of radiotherapy in Lincoln Hospital and I want you to know how pleased and impressed I am with the receptionists I met and the radiotherapists who treated me. Without exception and over more than seven weeks of treatment, they were polite, cheerful, business-like and compassionate. Though members of a busy department, they made a much-appreciated connection with me and other patients. I need hardly describe to you the importance of the positive tone they set, especially in the face of some patients’ fear and despair. Congratulations to those who assembled such a fine team.

author: GW2020
title: I got there 5 minutes late and was told they would not see me
body: So after arriving at the hospital and trying to find the clinic with the clear as mud signs, I got there 5 minutes late where I was told they would not see me. Twenty pounds down in taxi fees. At my next appointment, I wonder if I will get seen bang on my appointment time?

title: Why are receptionists asking asking clinical…
body: Today, I witnessed receptionists carrying out clinical triage to decide whether a patient's presenting condition warranted an appointment with a doctor or even a nurse. THIS IS MADNESS!

readBy.name: Sheffield Health and Social Care NHS Foundation Trust

title: Stress Control Course - give it a try
body:
Just completed the HiM Stress Control Course. I found it very interesting and helpful. At the beginning you may think that it's not relevant to you but stick with it and if you are suffering from stress you'll pick up useful tips. I found the sections on controlling your thoughts and getting a good night's sleep particularly good.
The HiM course is a series of presentations. You just have to listen and you can ask questions if you wish. There's no group discussion sessions and you aren't expected to talk about your own issues.
The course has given me plenty of practical ways to reduce stress and I would certainly recommend it.

title: Doctor.
body: Sadly my Mum passed away suddenly in November.  The doctor was wonderful to all my family, including my Dad.  Her kindness and empathy was truly well received by us all.  She really is an exceptional GP.

author: Tr21
title: Beautiful Maternity Care
body:
Our son was born at the BGH via an unplanned C-section on Monday and, thanks to EVERY SINGLE member of staff we came into contact with, the experience was beautiful and empowering despite trying circumstances. It would seem that a pre-requisite to working in the maternity services is that you have to be a saint! We were induced on Ward 17 and did a lot of labouring there in the first instance. The staff were attentive and compassionate, doing everything they could to ensure that we were as comfortable and happy as two first time parents experiencing labour can be! We were then transferred to the labour suite where Louise looked after us with such humanity that my husband still finds it hard to talk about without tearing up. We were allowed to make the labour room our own with battery-operated tea lights and music. Every step of the labouring process was talked through with us and we felt totally empowered throughout. After an expertly administered epidural I was even able to almost enjoy the experience! After a lack of progress we were advised by Dr. Rigby that a caesarean was the best option and, within a couple of hours, we were in theatre. The theatre staff were chatty and jovial and completely put us at ease in an alien situation. Maxine, the anaesthetist, talked us through every step and was very attentive. Again, we were allowed to make the theatre our own with our own choice of music. After our son was born were transferred back to Ward 17. The staff on the ward were, yet again, absolute angels and made us all feel secure and heard. We left the hospital with a beautiful baby boy and only positive memories of the entire experience.  
It would be hard to overstate how professional and empathetic every member of staff we came into contact with was. Words would not describe how beautiful the service is here, even if baby brain had allowed me to access all of them! I could not recommend the BGH enough to those looking for a positive experience of one of the most revolutionary events a person can go through.

title: Fantastic caring service
body: I had to bring my 92 year old mother to the emergency eye clinic on Sunday 19th January. From my initial phone call, to her being seen the same day, the service she received was fantastic. Special thanks to the doctor that she saw, for such thoughtful  and caring treatment of my mother.

readBy.name: The Royal Bournemouth and Christchurch Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Excellent service
body: Can not thank the male nurse who treated me,so helpful,informative and certainly put my mind at rest,plus a really nice guy,had a blood test taken and rang him back next morning for results,better service than my GP

readBy.name: Blackpool Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Great
body: I’ve recently moved to Loxford practice and I must say the doctors here are very accommodating , lovely and approachable. Pleasant people . Specially doctor one particular doctor, Brilliant doctor ❤️

title: Great Staff
body:
We attended a Early Morning weekend appointment in Castle Outpatients.
We were greeted by a lovely nurse, who then done an ECG.
The Doctor came and greeted us and informed us she was just helping other staff but we would be seen to asap.
The Doctor was very attentive and answered all of our questions thoroughly.
We were given plenty of time and a thorough examination was performed.
Having previously been to a different hospital I can honestly say I can't recommend Guildford enough.
Right from arrival to discharge we were made to feel relaxed and well cared for.
Everything was explained to us, medication reviewed. Options offered.
The Doctor was in my opinion amazing.

readBy.name: Royal Surrey County Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: As it should be!
body:
Helpful staff, knowledgeable Doctors and Nurses, good appointment availability (including early morning), able to do quite a lot in house (which avoids referral to Hospital for comparatively minor things. Good use of IT.

Keep it up!

title: Great service
body: The medical team were very professional and  the service that I received was outstanding.I would recommend Spa Medica to anybody

author: Cinderita
title: There should be experienced staff
body:
Unfortunately this has happened a good few times now. But my last visit was the last straw. I don't normally complain, but how can the service improve if no one is saying anything.  
At Elgin A&E staff always seem to be newly qualified, and it just seems to me like no one knows what they are doing.  
The last person I saw, leaned into my face and was talking to me I felt cheekily, talking down, talking over me, contradicting my illness which they clearly didn't know much about. I had to then wait a lot longer due to me asking to see someone else after myself explaining that I felt this staff member was being rude.  
At 4am, when you have came into hospital to recieve help since you cant breath, you don't ever want to be treated like this, the staff member was quite happy to put me out the door, after not even looking down my throat, or looking at my previous notes.  
Previously before that, I had been in and out of A&E regularly, at least once a month, sometimes every 2 weeks. For about 9 months.  
I had to explain that ibuprofen makes me very ill and cannot take it for my condition (endometriosis)  
So their answer was to give me a higher anti inflammatory.  
Which I came to this conclusion that it was that that was making me a lot worse, so when I was ill, I would take the medication, thinking it would help, and ended up in there every 2 weeks with worse symptoms.  
They thought I had anaphylaxis, due to the stomach inflamed, and arms and hands cold and tingling, I could not walk and thought I might die, I was in that much physical agony.  
I really think that they should be ensuring that they read patients medical notes before or during seeing them.  
And feel that they are just sometimes not experienced enough, and some can be very rude. Probably due to being understaffed.  
The A&E department I feel, should not be a place where students get to experiment on something as important as the human body, there should be experienced staff ready for what ever comes into the doors at any point.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)
Office of Rhoda Grant, MSP for Highlands and Islands

author: dayleyward
title: A follow-up call would have benefited me greatly
body:
Whilst utilising the day ward at Grantham hospital, the nurses and doctors were absolutely brilliant! Kept me calm and were really friendly, having a good laugh with me during my wait for surgery. Although very busy were always at hand for anything I needed and very accommodating. I was nervous at the beginning but thanks to the staff it made me relax and put me at ease.  
After my surgery I don’t recall much as was recovering from the anaesthetic. I vaguely remember a conversation in the theatre but not what was said. A few days later I had no recollection of being given a discharge note, what they had done or what was said.  
A follow-up call the next day or two would have benefited me greatly, as the pre and post-op notes I was given had different explanations as to what had actually been done in surgery on the day.

author: Mr Anonymous
title: In safe hands with professional people
body:
I attended A&E after falling at height from a tree.  
From the moment I entered the hospital site help was on hand. There was wheelchair available and I was booked in promptly by the lady on reception who had all my details accurately held.  
My initial observations were taken within 30 minutes. It wasn't long before I was assessed by a doctor who I felt was thorough and clear with what he was actioning.  
I went for a scan and was dealt with quickly and again clearly explained what to expect from the lady doing the scan. She helped promptly by others as I needed assistance moving around.  
On returning back to where I was being treated I was administered pain relief and had further obs taken. My results from my scan and my bloods were not that long coming through and I was okay to leave. Before leaving the doctor was clear what I had to do over the coming days and reassured me that further help was on hand should I feel the need to be back in touch.  
I felt the quality of the care and attention I received from all those who attended to my needs was very good and a credit to the hospital. There could have been up to 9 people that were in and out but all were excellent. In my case I was thankfully in pain but not broken. I felt in very safe hands with professional people.

readBy.name: York and Scarborough Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

author: Buddlia
title: A great service
body:
I was referred by my GP to AMU because she suspected I had a heart problem. She referred me at 9.45am. I was seen within 15 mins of arriving was treated with kindness and courtesy by everyone, from the receptionist to consultant. Tests were carried out, thorough examinations made and checked and results fed back to me promptly. Fortunately my concerns were allayed and I was able to return home, I had a follow up phone call from the doctor at AMU later that day.  
I don't think positive feedback is shared often enough so please make sure the AMU team read this.  
Thankyou to all. What a great service.

readBy.name: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

author: kat57
title: The staff were fantastic
body: Fell at home, admitted via A and E, spent night on Ward 4, discharged following day. The staff were fantastic, so helpful and caring. I felt listened to.

title: Very helpful
body:
Visited this morning with 2 queries.
Reception staff dealt with one quickly - 2 week wait for non-urgent health checkup appointment seemed fair.
Doctor & Reception staff managed 2nd query quickly & efficiently.
Thank you very much team.

author: supporting partner
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: Starting journey
body:
Didnt know where to go for help to start with  
CGL staff friendly and make you feel comfortable.  
Treatment isnt quick enough may have to wait a couple of weeks to go on prescription and needed the help today!  
Staff professional and non judgemental.  
Staff welcoming and explained things clearly

title: Snobby receptionist
body:
After taking a week to get an appointment I attended reception 15 minutes early for my 8.45 appointment, at 9.19 I went to the reception desk to as if I had been forgotten, the receptionist spoke to myself like poo on her shoe and simply told to get a ticket like everyone else. I refuse to be abused like this, I am a normal person,
I didn’t get my appointment as impossible to get an appointment.

author: Brora
title: Community equipment store
body:
Waited to have a large amount of equipment collected fro my aunt's house. To be collected between 9.00 am and 3.00 pm onset date. I called to ask if there was any chance of a rough time advised no.  
Van driver called me a pm to say they could not collect today. They always do collections pm as the van is empty.  
I waited in all day when the collection was always going to be pm. Could the person I spoke to not have told me this?  
This is equipment my aunt no longer needs as she is in the hospice and not returning home. Equipment needs to be back in circulation ASAP for other users. This was a day lost waiting when I could have been with her.

title: Been with surgery for 28 years
body: I have been with the surgery for 28 years. All these years the service has been brilliant. I am really happy.

title: Good staff
body: The staff at the east end medical centre are very professional. They really care for their practice and their wishes.

author: Tiredteacher
title: Treated thoroughly and with kindness, patience and respect.
body:
I recently underwent day surgery for a Gynae procedure. I was seen for my initial appointment with the gynaecologist within weeks of my GP's referral. I then had my Pre Op a few weeks later and my surgery was scheduled shortly after. The staff at all levels from start to finish were outstanding and an absolute credit to their profession.  
On the day of my surgery itself I had my procedure explained to me thoroughly by the Consultant, and was seen by the anaesthetist. Both explained the procedure thoroughly and found the time to answer my questions.  
I was then given a bed, and the nurse Hayley chatted to me and explained the process etc. The student Nurse again was brilliant at making me feel at ease whilst she took my obs. Nothing was too much trouble.  
It was obvious to see that the staff were under pressure, they work long shifts and with very limited resources but at every stage of the way they took their time when dealing with a various mix of patients on a full ward. They really should be congratulated on the work they do whilst maintaining a smile. I absolutely couldn't fault them.  
I did feel annoyed when other patients at times I felt made unnecessary demands and had unrealistic expectations of very busy clinical staff who were helping them by attending to them on wards when they were obviously needed elsewhere in the hospital. I just wish people could see that the NHS is at breaking point and demanding processes and procedures happen as to when you think they should rather than when there is time is unfair and places additional pressures on staff.  
I really cannot fault the staff on ward 2/4 and all of the staff in Pre Op. You are amazing. Thank you

title: Staff are helpful
body: The staff are very helpful and the treatment and care provided is excellent. They can improve the appointment booking system as it puts a lot of pressure on reception staff.

author: Re assured patient
title: I received wonderful care
body:
Upon arrival at Ward In (Gyneacology), I was made very welcome. I was shown into the Consultant’s room after a minimal wait. The procedure was thoroughly explained to myself and my husband and I was reassured that if at any time I was in any pain or discomfort, I could ask for the procedure to be halted.  
During the procedure, the Consultant was assisted by two members of Nursing Staff, there were a further two nurses present who seemed to be there for my benefit. They did an amazing job of reassuring and calming me throughout.  
I am happy to wholeheartedly recommend the Gynaecology department at Pilgrim hospital. I received wonderful care and was treated with respect by every member of staff that I met. Thank you*****

title: Good Practice
body: This is a very good GP surgery and I would definitely recommend. The receptionist, staff and doctors are all very professional and can book in advance. It is easy to access by public transport.

title: Good Surgery
body: The surgery is vey good. All are staff working there are knowledgeable. Really happy with the service

title: Medical Secretary
body: The service of the medical secretary is very good. She helps all the time when required and I recommend the surgery to other people. They are always helpful, kind and respectful.

author: JAS20
title: Waiting time for our son's surgery
body:
I am writing this , on behalf of my 4 year old son.  
Following meetings with Speech and Language, Specialist Children’s Services, with our son, my husband and myself requested that a referral should be made to check our son’s hearing. In March 2019, we were told that a referral for Ear, Nose and Throat had been made. Aware that waiting lists within the NHS are long, we waited with great patience. This was a wait of approximately 8 months.  
After chasing this up, we were informed by Speech & Language in November 2019 that the referral had not been processed properly. Approximately an hour after this call, S&L phoned my husband back , stating that they had emailed Audiology in March, to request that our son required an assessment of his hearing. However, after writing to the Head of Paediatric Audiology regarding this, I received a voicemail on 6th December 2019 stating that the referral from S&L, dated 22nd March 2019 was never received by the Paediatric Audiology department.  
It is then stated that S&L contacted the department in November 2019, asking why there had been no appointment given. We were then told, due to the amount of time we had been waiting, that the department was able to offer us a cancellation appointment at the end of November and that our son had now been referred onto ENT. Audiologists diagnosed mild to moderate hearing loss measured within the sound field and suspected that he had glue ear. Again, due to the time we had been waiting, they managed to get us an appointment with ENT, Clinic 7 Outpatients, to see a consultant. The consultant assessed our son and said that he would require Grommets and Adenoid surgery.  
We were then contacted by the Waiting List co-ordinator in December, to inform us that our son was on the waiting list for surgery, however there would be a minimum of 3 months waiting time but it could be longer. I felt that this was a very generic letter that did not take into consideration the time that my son had already been waiting. I decided to state my concerns in a letter of response which was addressed to the Waiting List Co-ordinator and was sent under the ‘Next day delivery’ service in December 2019. Again, mindful of the Christmas and New Year period, I waited patiently for a reply. After waiting over 4 weeks, I decided to phone the waiting list co-ordinator, on the number provided on the letter. I explained my son’s situation and they were unable to help but they were able to give me the number of their complaints line. I phoned this and spoke to a waiting list co-ordinator, whom was aware of the letter I had sent. They said that a reply had been sent out in early January. I have yet to receive this reply.  
On talking to her and explaining the situation, she told me that the Speech and Language, Specialist Children’s Services were independent of the hospital. Given that the S&L letters are headed with an ‘NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde’ logo, it gave us the impression that S&L were working in partnership with the hospital or at very least the NHS?? However , apparently not and therefore they had to go with the referral date that was given by the QEUH in December 2019, as opposed to the original date in March 2019. Furthermore, I was then told that the current waiting time is now 15 months! How is this fair on my 4 year old son, who has been waiting this whole time???  
I explained that my son has experienced difficulty with communication at nursery, as a result of his hearing impairment and given that he is due to start school this August, we need our son to be fitted with temporary hearing aids until he is given surgery(as was previously discussed with audiology). The waiting list co-ordinator emailed the Head of paediatric Audiology, to ask them to contact me. I have yet to hear from them.  
This has been an extremely stressful and anxious wait where my son has suffered terribly from multiple ear infections. Chasing this up with emails, letters and phone calls has been very time-consuming and costly, when we have ensured mail is sent with the ‘Next Day Delivery’ service.  
Our aim now is to get our son appointed for surgery at a time when he *should* have been, according to our original referral date and ensure that he is fitted with temporary hearing aids as a matter of urgency. Right now, we do not know who to turn to next, for the help our son needs.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students
Royal College of Speech and Language Therapists (RCSLT)
Office of Johann Lamont, MSP for Glasgow Pollok

author: Rusty00
title: You all make such a difference
body: My husband was recently in Ward 4B at the QEUH having a stem cell transplant.   The care he received from the ancillary staff to the consultants was first class.   Nothing was too much trouble and he was cared for with kindness and compassion.   Thanks to all in the Ward, you all make such a difference to patients and relatives during difficult times.

title: Fantastic contraception service
body:
Fantastic service at Morum House.
I went for a coil fitting and had my baby twins with me. The staff were incredibly kind and supportive, the appointment ran smoothly and the fitting was done smoothly.
I was given time and space to feed the babies and the staff helped me with them.
All in all highly recommended.

title: Excellent staff
body: I was due to have a blood test, I was quite nervous as I am not the biggest fan of needles. But the staff I saw were amazing, they took my mind off it and I actually felt at ease with the whole process. Sounds weird to say but the lady who took my blood was really nice!

author: Minor opp
title: Minor opp
body:
A bit anxious.  
Check-in staff working on a sheet and could not find my appointment they decided to check the computer and found it. Why not work from the computer for all appointments.  
Didn’t have to wait long.  
Staff in the appointment room were chatty and made me feel at ease.  
It was not a long opp so left after 45 mins.  
Had no further issues.

readBy.name: Office of Angus MacDonald, MSP for Falkirk East

title: Rude staff and terrible support
body: The new system is completely flawed, it is just a way for GP's not to see patients anymore. I will be informing CQC of the continued poor service.

author: Sparticus
title: Hardworking and good humoured
body:
I was rather nervous about having treatment which involved a cystoscopy and ultrasound. All appointments were timely after seeing my GP and were on time at the hospital. The staff were courteous, considerate and supportive, at all times showing concern and appropriate humour! Much needed light relief! Everyone at the ultrasound dept and urology dept were professional and deserve much praise.  
Excellent people; hard working and good humoured. Very well done, hats off to you all.

author: Ml32
title: Doctors treating Varicose veins
body:
I have a varicose vein that runs down through my kneecap. I have had pain with it for months. if I walk on it my knee weakens and eventually buckles from under me. I was told by my doctor the NHS no longer treat varicose veins so have put up with the pain, however, since Friday it has been like a constant ache. The pain is always on my knee & at the side and occasionally travels down my leg & i have been taking painkillers since Friday (it's a constant pain, a bit like toothache) . Again the doc has given me voltarol & advised me to buy compression socks as NHS no longer deal with varicose veins. Your NHS website however advises me that there may be other treatments. Could someone please advise me on what steps if any I can take next if any?  
Thanks

author: Red poppy
title: Took time to explain everything
body:
I underwent an MTP fusion at the Day surgery unit Queen Margaret Hospital.  
Mr Dall was my surgeon, and I could not have received better care and information from him. He took time to explain everything about my op. Some of which I was not aware of. I thank him very much for his concern about how I would be after the op as I was originally booked in to have both feet done at the same time. I am glad now that after discussing this with him I only had one foot done and the other will be done at a later date, hopefully not to many months from now. The nursing staff in the day surgery ward namely Karen and Lisa were fantastic. So caring and reassuring. Karen noticed I was a bit anxious and all it took from her was an arm round the shoulder and a bit of reassurance to make me relax a bit. They were both so attentive to all the patients, it was the best experience I have had from any of my hospital visits over the years. Thankyou again ladies you are both a credit to your nursing profession. I hope you are on duty when I get my other foot done. I felt safe and secure in your hands. All the staff were brilliant that day. The theatre staff were jolly and made you feel relaxed. I thank you, as it is a bit scary for patients.  
[Unsure about 'Team work']  
[Very happy with 'Staff attitude']

author: LL-2020
title: Maternity care
body:
I cannot speak highly enough of the care we have received throughout my pregnancy, during the birth of our daughter; and that continues presently during our first whirlwind months as new parents.  
We had a straightforward pregnancy but an unexpectedly complex birth. Both my partner and I are grateful beyond words for the expertise of the team around us at that time, their compassion and professionalism. We could not have asked for more.  
In particular we would like to thank Dr Chiswick, consultant obstetrician, Dr Simpson, obstetric anaesthetist, and Amber, midwife / nurse in charge of ward 211.  
Also Julie, the midwife, and Megan, the health visitor from Tollcross Health Centre, Edinburgh.

title: Terrible appointment system
body: Have been calling all day and only got threw at 2pm, appointment in relation to mental health. Despite new laws stating appointments for mental health must be seen on the same day i was told to wait until tomorrow or next week.

author: ppl0
title: Sigmoidoscopy examination
body:
I attended the Gastroenterology Unit for a Sigmoidoscopy examination with great trepidation. I was admitted on time, everything was explained to me in a private room by an experienced and caring nurse and within half an hour I was taken to the treatment room. In the treatment room I was set at ease by the doctor that performed the procedure and the two nurses that helped with calming my nerves, encouraging me, the gas and air and maintained my dignity during the procedure. Great work by all the staff.  
The only improvement I would make is I was asked to complete a questionnaire on my medical history when I first arrived in reception, I feel that this would be better sent out with the appointment letter so that it could be better completed and brought to the appointment on the day.

readBy.name: Blackpool Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: A Credit to the Mental Health System
body:
I recently spent some time in Beech Ward at Rochford Hospital 
I have nothing but admiration for all of the team from the Doctors,Nurses Cleaning and Catering staff
The quality of Care and attention was fantastic and so very helpful and understanding 
A real Credit to the Mental Health System and a Shining example to the NHS

readBy.name: Essex Partnership University NHS Foundation Trust

author: Lynneb311
title: Exceptional quality of care from all staff
body: I had surgery, a lumpectomy and lymph node removal for breast cancer. I received exceptional quality of care from all staff involved, but particularly from the theatre staff and the anaesthetist Dr Aldridge. Because of a pre-existing heart disease, every attention to detail was made to ensure I survived surgery without any adverse effect. In theatre before surgery all staff were very caring, friendly and reassuring. After surgery, Dr Aldridge very kindly contacted my husband to let him know I was ok. I was kept overnight for monitoring on Hatton ward an HDU surgical ward, where again I was looked after very attentively. The following morning I received courtesy visits from Mr Aldridge, Sandra a member of the theatre team, the Breast care nurse who gave me advice on post-operative care and the surgeon Mr Nair. All of this went a long way to making this experience less scary and unpleasant than it could have been.

title: Fantastic Improvements to a (now) Great Practice
body: We did have a wonderful surgery until ACE took over.  Since they have been fired and the Dr and the Ranworth team took over Caradoc is back to its fantastic level of surgery and care.  They listen to the patient, and we can now speak to a receptionist not some awful call centre.  Well done everyone.

title: best asthma clinic
body: I am so fortunate to have a nurse who is so experienced and knowledgeable in helping me live with asthma.  She gives me the advice I need to hear to keep healthy and gently guides me into making good health decisions.  She is an absolute credit to the practice and nursing profession.  I have found her support and level of care amazing and wouldn't want to be looked after by anyone else.

title: Thank you
body: I am house bound and my son has to arrange home visits on my behalf as I could never get through on the old system.  Now the surgery take the calls I am able to speak with a receptionist.  The doctor even called me and the paramedic ladies who came out to me were very caring and knowledgeable.  Thank you all.  It is nice to have my old doctor  back as I missed hime when I moved from Clacton to Frinton.

title: Great care
body: Many thanks to the staff on Newquay Hospital ward who looked after one of my friends. Excellent care and support given to him and his family during a very sad time.

author: kittikat
title: Cannot fault the attention I received
body:
After my stay in the Intensive Care Unit, I was transferred to Falcon Ward in Abbey Wing where I spent three days before being discharged beginning of December.  
I am writing to say a huge thank you to all the staff at St Peter’s Hospital for the attention and kindness I have received in all areas. From my Surgeon, Mr Nisar, the Anaesthetists, and all the nursing staff who, although very short-staffed (rushed off their feet), never gave anything but 100% attention to looking after myself and the other patients. I cannot fault the attention I have received (even down to the cleaning staff). If there is any way of saying thank you to all the people involved in my care would you please somehow convey my very grateful thanks to them.  
My only regret is that I could not do justice to any of the fantastic meals served up three times a day and all the different choices on the weekly menu. Missed the syrup sponge as one of the puddings on Friday evening as I was discharged on Friday afternoon!!  
Thank you so very much.

readBy.name: Ashford and St Peter's Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Always happy with service
body:
Dr’s have been extremely helpful each time and clear and communicate with me.
The reception are polite if sometimes a little stand offish

title: hard to get a doctors appointment
body: I can never get through on the phone to try and get an appointment today I have been on the phone in a queue for 35 minutes and still waiting. I was no 7 in the queue when I started.  no update of where I am in the queue just very loud annoying music being played.  know wonder people just turn up at A&E.

title: Can’t change appointment
body: I tried to ring to cancel my physio apt, but no one was able to put me through, I tried N&N but they couldn’t help. It’s crazy that a busy department has no contact information on the website! I’m surely not the only one.

readBy.name: Norfolk Community Health and Care NHS Trust

title: Colonoscopy
body:
I was so worried about having my colonoscopy, but there really wasn’t any need to be. From the moment I walked into the clinic I knew I was in safe hands. The receptionist was friendly and welcoming, and the environment was spotlessly clean. I only waited a few minutes before being called in by the pre assessment nurse who reassured me about the colonoscopy. Then met the consultant who would perform the procedure, again he was very friendly and reassuring, by this point I wasn’t nervous at all. Then when I went into the procedure room I was met by 2 AMAZINGLY kind nurses who looked after me so well, and before I knew it the procedure was over. I didn’t feel a thing! In recovery the care and attention continued. 

I really can’t praise this practice enough. Each and every member of staff I met were fantastic, and a true credit to our NHS. Thank you so much.

readBy.name: Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust

title: Terrible GP
body: The staff never  answer the phone, very bad service.

title: nurse
body: I came and saw a nurse on Thursday, she was really helpful and welcomed me very nicely. Provided excellent care and explained what she is doing really well. She really understood my issues and gave me the appropriate care and dealt with all of my queries. The previous nurses never explained care well and I have never been welcomed as nicely as I was on Thursday. My only request to the surgery is that you need more nurses like this!
